Exclusion zone (EZ) water droplet experiment. (Water droplets occasionally float on water due to a property of water referred to as EZ water) when water comes in contact with other materials, it's properties and molecular structure actually shift at the point of contact (from H2O to H3O2) creating what is called the exclusion zone. You should reallcy check it out, it's super badass, would love to see the droplets in action in slow motion.

The other day I was installing a new kitchen faucet and after I was all done I had realized I accidentally put some 100% silicone caulking on my Tshirt. I tried to wipe it off as much as I could but it still left a few marks. I was hoping it would come off in a regular wash but it didn’t. It still left a few 1-2 inch spots.
 
It gave me an idea of putting silicone all over the Tshirt and wiping it off just to leave a thin coat but I haven’t tried that idea yet. Maybe it would turn it in a water resistant shirt lol.
 
Maybe you guys could try to coat some items (mostly clothing) with a thin coat of 100% silicone caulking and let it dry to see what kind of result it would do. I know there’s spray you can buy that will probably do the same but caulking is usually cheaper and would be interesting to see how it reacts with certain things. If the items would become somewhat water resistant.
